summary: Liverpudlian actress Jodie Comer cut her teeth in domestic drama Doctor Foster, but has now found household name fame with viral...
body:
Liverpudlian actress Jodie Comer cut her teeth in domestic drama Doctor Foster, but has now found household name fame with viral BBC cat-and-mouse hit, Killing Eve.

The star takes to the cover of the Winter 18/19 issue, interviewed by Lily Walker, styled by Toni-Blaze and shot by Adam Whitehead.

Pre-order now.

blog.name: angiespotter
blog.title: otium tibi molestum est
blog.description: Anna. 27. Italian. Anthropologist. My dogs are my life and joy in this world. I'm probably too angry and hungry to be barely 5'2''. I tag spoilers, if you don't see something tagged just ask and I will add it. If you want to blacklist something beside spoilers: my personal posts are listed under "personal" or "ignore", while my fandom rants/angry posts/live blogging are "angie rants".

summary: Ok, I’ve just started watching Killing Eve and can I just say I loved that they hired Italian actors to play Italian characters?...
body: Ok, I’ve just started watching Killing Eve and can I just say I loved that they hired Italian actors to play Italian characters? It was lovely to not hear my language being literally butchered by a vaguely Mediterranean-looking brit who took a week of Italian courses like…YES, THEY DID THAT!

reblog.comment: Ok, I’ve just started watching Killing Eve and can I just say I loved that they hired Italian actors to play Italian characters? It was lovely to not hear my language being literally butchered by a vaguely Mediterranean-looking brit who took a week of Italian courses like…YES, THEY DID THAT!

summary: Wow I just want a series of Villanelle and Irina running around being petty little criminal shits together instead of whatever...
body:
Wow I just want a series of Villanelle and Irina running around being petty little criminal shits together instead of whatever that bullshit was in the restaurant with Villanelle just letting Irina go.

They would have been an amazing little girl gang of two together.

summary: i’m not really that upset about this tumblr thing because I genuinely don’t think I or any of my friends’ accounts did anything...
body:
i’m not really that upset about this tumblr thing because I genuinely don’t think I or any of my friends’ accounts did anything wrong but like. now everybody has got me all paranoid. idk man. i think everything it getting blown out of proportion. i just dont have the energy in me to care right now. i really dont. 

im just so tired these days…im so tired…

summary: It’s a Great Time to Be Watching TV—and a Weird Time to Be Ranking It
title: It’s a Great Time to Be Watching TV—and a Weird Time to Be Ranking It
excerpt: The Ringer’s Best Shows of 2018 list is our attempt at presenting a broader picture of the year in TV. But the joy of watching television these days is that everyone can have a different favorite show.
description:
If Killing Eve stood in contrast to television audiences’ divided nature, Succession embodied it. In raw viewership, its numbers were small but steady, though they peaked with the finale, suggesting overall growth. In critical reception, the overall consensus was generally positive, if initially more muted than Eve’s. But consensus, by definition, only applies to an aggregate. Broken down to individuals, opinions on Succession were sharply split. Some, including the members of this website, christened it the best show on air at the time; others decried what they saw as its muddled tone, though over the course of a 10-episode season its reputation improved enough to occasion some mea culpas. Those who loved Succession loved it; those who didn’t, didn’t. It’s how everyone feels about almost everything on air these days, but more.

Ultimately, top honors went to Killing Eve—mostly because I believe it to be the stronger show, but also because, in this case, defying a trend seems more noteworthy than exemplifying one. Yet the fact remains that 2018 saw many more shows like Succession, and not just because Succession operates within a time-honored tradition of ogling—and scorning—the rich. This was a year when excellence was very much in the eye of the beholder, and there were as many best shows on TV as there were people making that pronouncement.

by Alison Herman

Click through above for the rest.
